author: By John Koblin, Michael M. Grynbaum and Tiffany Hsu
title: Tension, Then Some Tears, as TV News Narrates a Moment for History
description: The news networks pledged restraint going into election night. Four days later, anchors waited until a fresh batch of Pennsylvania votes allowed them to project a winner.
content: The tension mounted for days — and then broke, all at once.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Kaplan
title: ‘We’re going to win this race,’ Biden says in brief address.
description: Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. urged patience on Friday as the vote count continued, but he expressed confidence in the coming result. The numbers “tell us a clear and convincing story,” Mr. Biden said in brief remarks just before 11 p.m. “We’re going to win this race.”
content: Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. urged patience on Friday as the vote count continued, but he expressed confidence in the coming result. The numbers “tell us a clear and convincing story,” Mr. Biden said in brief remarks just before 11 p.m. “We’re going to win this race.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joumana Khatib
title: Short Stories Need a Defender. She’s Ready.
description: Danielle Evans talks about “The Office of Historical Corrections,” a “slightly weirder” book than her last, and the comfort of not being the only Black writer in the conversation.
content: Danielle Evans really did mean to write a novel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise
title: Celebrations break out in the streets of Washington, about a mile from the White House.
description: WASHINGTON — Strangers were congratulating each other on the streets of the nation’s capital in the hour after major news outlets declared Joseph R. Biden Jr. as the winner of the presidential race.
content: WASHINGTON — Strangers were congratulating each other on the streets of the nation’s capital in the hour after major news outlets declared Joseph R. Biden Jr. as the winner of the presidential race.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Rutenberg, Alan Feuer, Nick Corasaniti and Reid J. Epstein
title: Where the Election Fight Is Playing Out in the Courts
description: The Trump campaign has intensified its efforts to stop vote counting and to question the validity of ballots, with nearly a dozen lawsuits in Nevada, Pennsylvania, Michigan and Georgia.
content: [Read more on Joe Biden’s president-elect acceptance speech.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: Weary ballot counters continue four days after vote as the nation waits for results.
description: Perhaps no one wants the election to end more than the vote counters themselves.
content: Perhaps no one wants the election to end more than the vote counters themselves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brent Staples
title: A Black Hero in the Jim Crow Navy
description: Dorie Miller saved lives at Pearl Harbor. He’s finally getting his due.
content: The Black press was at the peak of its influence as the country geared up for World War II — while segregating even the plasma in the wartime blood bank by race. Fire-breathing newspapers like The Baltimore Afro-American, The Chicago Defender and The Pittsburgh Courier were religiously passed from home to home and read aloud in Black barbershops. Even the marginally literate understood that Black men who had volunteered to fight and die for the country were being persecuted on military bases and housed in Jim Crow barracks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sydney Ember
title: Treasury Secretary Warren? Progressives Line Up to Press Their Agenda on Biden
description: With control of the Senate unclear, liberal Democrats are trying to figure out how to achieve their policy goals through the White House.
content: They have an extensive blacklist for possible Biden appointees they do not like. They want to elevate allies like Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont to premier government posts. And they are even considering the possibility of bypassing Senate approval to fill executive branch roles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck and Thomas Kaplan
title: Biden makes his first remarks to the nation as president-elect.
description: WILMINGTON, Del. — Joseph R. Biden Jr. addressed the nation for the first time as president-elect on Saturday night, delivering a message of unity and trying to soothe the extraordinary divisions that defined the last four years in American politics.
content: WILMINGTON, Del. — Joseph R. Biden Jr. addressed the nation for the first time as president-elect on Saturday night, delivering a message of unity and trying to soothe the extraordinary divisions that defined the last four years in American politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sean Keenan
title: An Atlanta election worker is in hiding after a claim that he tossed a ballot. His boss says the claim is false.
description: ATLANTA, Ga. — A man working at a vote-counting site in Atlanta earlier this week has gone into hiding after being wrongly accused of discarding a ballot, according to Richard Barron, elections director for Georgia’s largest county, Fulton.
content: ATLANTA, Ga. — A man working at a vote-counting site in Atlanta earlier this week has gone into hiding after being wrongly accused of discarding a ballot, according to Richard Barron, elections director for Georgia’s largest county, Fulton.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner and Photographs by Dan Balilty
title: ‘It’s Like Falling in Love’: Israeli Entrepreneurs Welcomed in Dubai
description: A high-profile delegation of Israeli innovators visited the United Arab Emirates soon after moves to normalize relations.
content: DUBAI — For years, Israeli entrepreneurs slipped in and out of the United Arab Emirates incognito, traveling on second passports or doing business through third parties.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oliver Burkeman
title: Why You Should Brave the ‘Bad’ Weather
description: My British upbringing taught me that socializing outdoors shouldn’t stop when rain falls and temperatures drop.
content: Winter is on its way. Here in the New York area, where I live, and throughout the Northeast, we can expect a few perfect days of cold, clear air and snow that sparkles in the sun; but the season’s dominant notes will most likely be rain, overcast skies, bone-chilling winds, an Arctic storm or two and more rain. For all of us who have relied on outdoor socializing to maintain our sanity this year, cherishing our walks in the park and our socially distanced stoop conversations, the change in the weather feels like the final affront. The pandemic grinds on; democracy seems to teeter on a precipice — and now we won’t even be able to get outside, to breathe fresh air and see our friends and neighbors. Or will we?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Craine
title: In photos: Going door to door to help cure ballots in Atlanta.
description: Today is the deadline for Georgia voters to correct issues with their ballots, known as curing. Volunteers went door-to-door throughout Atlanta and elsewhere in the state to help voters with rejected absentee ballots make the corrections.
content: Today is the deadline for Georgia voters to correct issues with their ballots, known as curing. Volunteers went door-to-door throughout Atlanta and elsewhere in the state to help voters with rejected absentee ballots make the corrections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber and Tara Siegel Bernard
title: For Millions Deep in Student Loan Debt, Bankruptcy Is No Easy Fix
description: It’s an extremely difficult debt to discharge, and only a few hundred people a year even try. Here are the stories of some who succeeded — mostly.
content: With two mortgages, three children and $83,000 in student loan debt, the financial strain finally became too much for George A. Johnson and Melanie Raney-Johnson.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Arango
title: Angelenos hope for unity after a divided presidential election.
description: LOS ANGELES — When Dolores Selico cast her vote for Joseph R. Biden Jr. in a high school gymnasium in South Los Angeles on Tuesday, she wore a T-shirt with the face of John Lewis, the Georgia congressman and civil rights pioneer who died in July. Her attire was to honor “what our ancestors went through so we could vote,” said Ms. Selico, 80, who is Black.
content: LOS ANGELES — When Dolores Selico cast her vote for Joseph R. Biden Jr. in a high school gymnasium in South Los Angeles on Tuesday, she wore a T-shirt with the face of John Lewis, the Georgia congressman and civil rights pioneer who died in July. Her attire was to honor “what our ancestors went through so we could vote,” said Ms. Selico, 80, who is Black.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danny Hakim, Stephanie Saul and Glenn Thrush
title: Stacey Abrams draws praise as Biden leads in Georgia.
description: Stacey Abrams, who was on a short list of potential vice-presidential candidates, was ultimately not chosen by Joseph R. Biden Jr.
content: Stacey Abrams, who was on a short list of potential vice-presidential candidates, was ultimately not chosen by Joseph R. Biden Jr.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nagourney
title: Presidency appears within Biden’s grasp as his lead widens in crucial battlegrounds.
description: Joe Biden hoped to deliver a victory address on Friday. Instead he called for calm as the nation awaits a winner.
content: The outdoor stage was all set in Wilmington, Del., for Joseph R. Biden Jr. to come out and address the nation — presumably in a victory speech as the president-elect.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti, Katie Glueck and Benjamin Mueller
title: Biden declared victor in hard-fought race for Pennsylvania.
description: Joe Biden wins Pennsylvania’s 20 electoral votes, giving him enough for the presidency.
content: PHILADELPHIA — Joseph R. Biden Jr. defeated President Trump in Pennsylvania, winning its 20 electoral votes and presidency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Victory for Joe Biden, at Last
description: Kamala Harris will make history as the first woman to serve as vice president.
content: Having peered into the abyss of autocratic nationalism, the American people have chosen to step back from the brink. The ballot counting will continue for a few days yet, but the math is what it is: Joe Biden will have the 270 electoral votes needed to win the White House, and likely many more. President Trump’s four-year assault on our democratic institutions and values will soon end.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: The scene at a ‘Count Every Vote’ rally in Bethlehem, Pa.
description: “In some of these local races it has come down to a handful of votes,” said Ashleigh Strange, one of the Pennsylvanians assembled, about the movement’s importance.
content: “In some of these local races it has come down to a handful of votes,” said Ashleigh Strange, one of the Pennsylvanians assembled, about the movement’s importance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Prosecutors in Kenosha Drop Sexual Assault Charge Against Jacob Blake
description: Mr. Blake, a 29-year-old Black man, was partly paralyzed after a white police officer shot him seven times in the back in Kenosha, Wis., in August, setting off protests.
content: Prosecutors on Friday dropped a sexual assault charge against Jacob Blake, a 29-year-old Black man who was partly paralyzed after a white police officer shot him seven times in the back in Kenosha, Wis., in August.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Perdue’s re-election race goes to a runoff in Georgia, leaving the Senate majority in limbo.
description: Senator David Perdue, Republican of Georgia, was fighting for his political life on Saturday in a contest that could determine which party controls the Senate, as his re-election bid headed to a January runoff against Jon Ossoff, his Democratic challenger.
content: Senator David Perdue, Republican of Georgia, was fighting for his political life on Saturday in a contest that could determine which party controls the Senate, as his re-election bid headed to a January runoff against Jon Ossoff, his Democratic challenger.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander Burns and Jonathan Martin
title: Leading in Pennsylvania, Biden Tells Nation, ‘We’re Going to Win This Race’
description: Joe Biden also pulled ahead in Georgia, and maintained leads in Nevada and Arizona. President Trump and his team weighed legal options, but lawsuits this week have had no meaningful effect on the tabulation of ballots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Michael D. Shear
title: Six in White House, Including Trump’s Chief of Staff, Have the Coronavirus
description: Mark Meadows aided President Trump’s efforts to play down the virus throughout the summer. A Trump campaign adviser and four other White House aides also tested positive.
content: Six White House aides and a Trump campaign adviser — including Mark Meadows, President Trump’s chief of staff — have contracted the coronavirus, officials said, raising fears of another outbreak sweeping through the ranks of the nation’s top officials as cases surge to record levels in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Barry, J. David Goodman and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: For Trump voters, shock, disappointment and disbelief.
description: Jodi Lavoie-Carnes, 48, a dental hygienist who lives in Dover, N.H., supported President Trump for re-election. On Saturday, she was shocked and disturbed by the boisterous celebrations of Biden supporters, who had gathered in her town waving profane anti-Trump signs.
content: Jodi Lavoie-Carnes, 48, a dental hygienist who lives in Dover, N.H., supported President Trump for re-election. On Saturday, she was shocked and disturbed by the boisterous celebrations of Biden supporters, who had gathered in her town waving profane anti-Trump signs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang
title: As Hong Kong Law Goes After ‘Black Sheep,’ Fear Clouds Universities
description: Campuses have long been hubs of protest in the city. Now, the authorities have promised to root out teachers who bring politics to the classroom.
content: HONG KONG — When Harry Wu, a professor of medical humanities at the University of Hong Kong, gave a lesson last fall about doctors’ responsibilities in society, he focused on a real-world example: the volunteer medics treating protesters and police in the antigovernment demonstrations convulsing the city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Rutenberg
title: President Trump vows to keep up legal battle after Joe Biden is declared the winner.
description: President Trump might be vowing to battle ahead in his bid to turn the tide of the presidential election despite unanimous, major media organization calls naming former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. the winner.
content: President Trump might be vowing to battle ahead in his bid to turn the tide of the presidential election despite unanimous, major media organization calls naming former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. the winner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon and Annie Karni
title: Biden Leads, but No Call Yet Four Days After Election: This Week in the 2020 Race
description: Election Day has turned into Election Week and while Joe Biden is within striking distance of 270 Electoral College vote, the counting is continuing.
content: Welcome to our weekly analysis of the state of the 2020 campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chibuihe Obi Achimba
title: Gay in Nigeria, Black Male in America
description: I learned how to carry myself to protect my safety back home, only to come to the U.S. and face a different danger.
content: I came to the United States in 2019 as a scholar-at-risk fellow at Harvard University. After I was kidnapped and tortured in Nigeria for being gay and daring to speak openly about it America offered me refuge. But this spring after videos of the killings of Ahmaud Arbery and George Floyd surfaced, I’m coming to terms with the fact that the country that promised me safety is one where Black men like me face a different kind of danger.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanie Riess
title: How Do You Advertise a Town Ravaged by Hurricanes?
description: Kathryn Shea Duncan, 24, works to promote tourism in Lake Charles, La., which was hit hard by Laura and Delta this year.
content: As a 24-year-old public relations representative for her city, Kathryn Shea Duncan eats, sleeps and breathes Lake Charles, La.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tressie McMillan Cottom
title: The Danger in White Moderates Setting Biden’s Agenda
description: With at most a narrow majority in the Senate, the new president will be inclined to do less. He must be pushed to do more.
content: The full contours of the postelection landscape are, as yet, unknown, but we’ve learned many important lessons already. Chief among them is that white Republicans will vote party over every other economic and social issue and that this will make it nearly impossible to govern.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: What’s a Runoff, and Why Are There Two? Here’s Why Georgia Matters
description: Neither of Georgia’s Republican senators drew a majority on Election Day, sending both of their races to special rematches in January that will likely determine control of the Senate.
content: As the dust settles from the presidential race, the eyes of the political world have already shifted to Georgia, where two runoff elections set for early January will almost certainly determine which party has control of the Senate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Rutenberg, Alan Feuer, Nick Corasaniti, Reid J. Epstein and Vivian Wang
title: The Supreme Court hands Trump a small victory in Pennsylvania’s vote count.
description: Nearly a dozen lawsuits filed by President Trump and his allies are working their way through the courts in Nevada, Pennsylvania, Michigan and Georgia, trying — so far unsuccessfully — to stop ballot counting and invalidate enough votes to erase Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s leads there. Here is a look at those cases.
content: Nearly a dozen lawsuits filed by President Trump and his allies are working their way through the courts in Nevada, Pennsylvania, Michigan and Georgia, trying — so far unsuccessfully — to stop ballot counting and invalidate enough votes to erase Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s leads there. Here is a look at those cases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Romero, Miriam Jordan and Michael Wines
title: Why Arizona’s Storied Conservative Stronghold Could Flip for Biden
description: Maricopa County spawned the careers of Republican hard-liners like Joe Arpaio. Now the children of immigrants targeted in the state’s nativist crackdown are challenging G.O.P. dominance.
content: PHOENIX — Ten years ago, Maricopa County was the place that spawned the political careers of Republican hard-liners like Joe Arpaio, the sheriff who demonized immigrants and placed inmates in a tent camp. Politicians from Phoenix and its suburbs thrived with appeals to voters on guns, religion and taxes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allyson Waller
title: Iceberg Headed for Sub-Antarctic Island Could Threaten Wildlife
description: The iceberg, known as A68a, broke apart from the Antarctic Peninsula in 2017 and has been drifting ever since.
content: An iceberg roughly the size of Delaware that is headed toward the sub-Antarctic island of South Georgia has experts worried about the possibility of it blocking wildlife from food sources and threatening the island’s ecosystem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eleanor Lutz, Allison McCann and Amy Schoenfeld Walker
title: What happens when the election results are contested?
description: As the country waits for ballot tallies in a handful of crucial battleground states, the Trump campaign has pursued lawsuits in Michigan and Pennsylvania, and said that it would demand a recount in Wisconsin.
content: As the country waits for ballot tallies in a handful of crucial battleground states, the Trump campaign has pursued lawsuits in Michigan and Pennsylvania, and said that it would demand a recount in Wisconsin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Felice Belman
title: With Van Drew’s victory in New Jersey, 2021 will be the rare year since 1946 without a Kennedy in Congress.
description: BOSTON — There has been a member of the Kennedy family in Congress nearly continuously since John F. Kennedy was first elected to the House of Representatives in 1946. But 2021, it seems, will be a rare exception.
content: BOSTON — There has been a member of the Kennedy family in Congress nearly continuously since John F. Kennedy was first elected to the House of Representatives in 1946. But 2021, it seems, will be a rare exception.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Rutenberg, Nick Corasaniti and Alan Feuer
title: With No Evidence of Fraud, Trump Fails to Make Headway on Legal Cases
description: The president appeared to have little path through the courts to shift the outcome of the election, leaving him reliant on long shots like recounts or pressure on state legislatures.
content: President Trump’s bellicose pledge to fight the outcome of the election in the courts crashed on Friday into skeptical judges, daunting Electoral College math and a lack of evidence for his claims of fraud.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Flegenheimer
title: Biden Knows Washington Has Changed. He’s Less Sure He Has To.
description: Preparing to assume the presidency in a divided country, Joe Biden confronts the ultimate test of his principal theory of governance: that compromise is good and modest progress is still progress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer, Sydney Ember and Jacey Fortin
title: Kamala Harris, elected V.P., has risen higher in national politics than any woman before her.
description: Kamala Harris, a senator from California and former presidential candidate, made history when she was elected vice president of the United States.
content: Kamala Harris, a senator from California and former presidential candidate, made history when she was elected vice president of the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: We Hereby Dump Trump
description: When it came to planning his postelection fight, Trump was an Apprentice.
content: WASHINGTON — We expected more of Donald Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edgar Sandoval
title: A Rollicking N.Y.C. Celebration for Biden’s Win, Well Into the Night
description: People cheered, danced, broke out champagne and honked horns in the city, which is President Trump’s hometown but had turned on him.
content: It started with a low rumble that sounded like faraway crowd noise coming from a football stadium. Then came the loud honking of car horns. Some people dashed out of their apartments and began dancing in the streets, joined by others who banged on pots and pans. One man popped open a bottle of champagne in the middle of a Brooklyn block.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Hurdle
title: In Philadelphia, protests wind down with dueling playlists.
description: PHILADELPHIA — Dueling protests by supporters of President Trump and Joseph R. Biden Jr. ended late Friday outside the Pennsylvania Convention Center, where Philadelphia’s votes are still being counted.
content: PHILADELPHIA — Dueling protests by supporters of President Trump and Joseph R. Biden Jr. ended late Friday outside the Pennsylvania Convention Center, where Philadelphia’s votes are still being counted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Acrostic
description: We are all strapped to a tiny spinning ball with Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon, hurtling into the future.
content: ACROSTIC — What a perfectly timed excerpt, eh? Its author, Katie Mack, is a modern astrophysicist, one of those scientists with the gift of bright and explanatory gab on social media. Its source is “The End of Everything,” Dr. Mack’s exploration of five different ways that our universe might transition to a drastically different state, to put it mildly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Phil Klay
title: The Human Experience Will Not Be Quantified
description: Why do we keep mistaking data for knowledge?
content: In March, when the first spike of Covid-19 cases in New York was filling hospitals and panicking the city, my immunocompromised mother-in-law and my eight-months pregnant wife both contracted the disease. At first, it was just like a bad cold, but soon my wife was crying in pain every time she coughed and my mother-in-law could barely get out of bed. As my mother-in-law’s oxygen levels ticked down day by day, I would listen to her breathing and wonder whether I should bring her to a hospital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany Hsu and Katie Robertson
title: ‘It’s a Big Deal’: TV Coverage Notes Magnitude of Kamala Harris Victory
description: On Fox News, Donna Brazile recalled that her mother and grandmother could not vote. “Just scoot over and let women also share in the leadership of this country,” she said.
content: Soon after the major television networks called the White House for Joseph R. Biden Jr. and devoted some time to discussing the coming end of the Trump presidency, they began taking note of a milestone: the ascendancy of the first female, first Black and first South Asian vice president-elect, Senator Kamala Harris of California.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Maslin Nir and Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: They were born before women could vote. Now they’re waiting to see one be vice president.
description: Two women, one 102, the other 107 years old, reflect on the possibility of Kamala Harris’s inauguration.
content: When Laura Franklin was born on Jan. 20, 1918, women could not vote.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Fatima Faizi
title: String of Attacks Have People in Kabul Pointing a Finger, at the Government
description: The assaults not only highlight a city under siege, they have exposed a growing, and very public, discontent with an Afghan government unable to protect its people.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — A famous journalist, the father of an oft-threatened mayor and at least 22 others, many of them university students — all were killed within the span of a week in Kabul, Afghanistan’s capital, the victims of targeted assassinations and a terrorist attack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: We Still Don’t Really Understand Trump — or America
description: Democrats expected better. What happened?
content: This column has been updated to reflect news developments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Gladstone
title: Biden to Face Long List of Foreign Challenges, With China No. 1
description: President Trump will be handing Joseph R. Biden Jr. a difficult cleanup act in America’s relations with many countries. But it may not take much for Mr. Biden to improve the mood.
source.name: The New York Times

title: It’s midnight on the East Coast. Here’s where things stand.
description: As Friday came to a close in the Eastern United States, the six states that will decide the next president remained uncalled. In a brief speech, Joseph R. Biden Jr. expressed confidence that he would prevail in the end, but it was clear that vote counting would carry into the weekend.
content: As Friday came to a close in the Eastern United States, the six states that will decide the next president remained uncalled. In a brief speech, Joseph R. Biden Jr. expressed confidence that he would prevail in the end, but it was clear that vote counting would carry into the weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan
title: As Virus Rate Surges to 6%, N.J. Governor Warns of Crackdown
description: Like New York, the state had beaten back the virus in the early days of the pandemic. Now, it is bracing for another battle.
content: A spike in Covid-19 cases has again put New Jersey on the cusp of imposing restrictions meant to keep the coronavirus at bay, officials said on Friday as the state saw around 2,000 new infections for a third straight day — a benchmark it last crossed in May.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives, Jennifer Medina and Dave Philipps
title: Biden defeats Trump in Nevada.
description: Joseph R. Biden Jr. won the state of Nevada on Saturday, according to The New York Times, defeating President Trump by two percentage points.
content: Joseph R. Biden Jr. won the state of Nevada on Saturday, according to The New York Times, defeating President Trump by two percentage points.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Campbell Robertson, Audra D. S. Burch and Sabrina Tavernise
title: Praying, Dancing, Waiting: Americans Hang On for the Election’s End
description: Some in Philadelphia danced as Joseph R. Biden Jr. pulled ahead in their state. Trump supporters held out hope.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany Hsu
title: Rachel Maddow Goes Into Coronavirus Quarantine
description: The MSNBC anchor said she had tested negative but planned to stay home after a “close contact” tested positive for the virus.
content: Rachel Maddow has devoted many of her prime-time monologues to criticism of President Trump over the last four years. Now Ms. Maddow, the top-rated MSNBC host, may not be on the air when her network delivers the final results of his re-election campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Margolies
title: The Good News/Bad News About Ice Skating at Rockefeller Center
description: Maybe the rink will lack tourists this winter, but there are plenty of cooped up New Yorkers who would appreciate it.
content: Since 1936, gliding on the ice at Rockefeller Center in the presence of golden Prometheus and a 75-foot Christmas tree, or watching others do so, has been a New York holiday tradition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: Democrats cheer ‘historic’ win as race is called for Biden and Harris.
description: Minutes after the 2020 presidential race was called for Joseph R. Biden Jr., and Kamala Harris, prominent Democrats supportive of the former Vice President and his running mate cheered their victory as the first step toward a brighter American future.
content: Minutes after the 2020 presidential race was called for Joseph R. Biden Jr., and Kamala Harris, prominent Democrats supportive of the former Vice President and his running mate cheered their victory as the first step toward a brighter American future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eleanor Lutz, Allison McCann and Amy Schoenfeld Walker
title: What happens when election results are contested?
description: As the country waits for ballot tallies in a handful of crucial battleground states, the Trump campaign has pursued lawsuits in Michigan and Pennsylvania, and said that it would demand a recount in Wisconsin.
content: As the country waits for ballot tallies in a handful of crucial battleground states, the Trump campaign has pursued lawsuits in Michigan and Pennsylvania, and said that it would demand a recount in Wisconsin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danny Hakim, Stephanie Saul and Glenn Thrush
title: As Biden Inches Ahead in Georgia, Stacey Abrams Draws Recognition and Praise
description: Celebrities, activists and voters credited Ms. Abrams for building a network of organizations that highlighted voter suppression and inspired an estimated 800,000 new voter registrations.
content: Stacey Abrams, who earlier this year was on a short list of potential vice-presidential candidates, was ultimately not chosen by Joseph R. Biden Jr. But on Friday, as Mr. Biden took a narrow lead in Georgia, it was Ms. Abrams who was celebrated, a sign of her remarkable ascent as a power broker since her failed bid for governor of that state two years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: After Warnings It Could Go Off the Rails, the Election Actually Ran Smoothly
description: Amid the logistical challenges of voting in a pandemic, and despite threats of foreign interference, violence and disinformation, the machinery of democracy held up quite well.
content: In Georgia, a high school senior organized her classmates to be poll workers so voters would not have to wait hours in line like they did back in June.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller
title: A close friend of Harris’s isn’t celebrating yet.
description: MORAGA, Calif. — Suzy Loftus has been Kamala Harris’s close friend and colleague for two decades. She worked on Ms. Harris’s first political campaign, a successful run for district attorney in San Francisco. She served as a senior adviser during Ms. Harris’s ascent to state and national politics, and they worked together at the state’s Justice Department.
content: MORAGA, Calif. — Suzy Loftus has been Kamala Harris’s close friend and colleague for two decades. She worked on Ms. Harris’s first political campaign, a successful run for district attorney in San Francisco. She served as a senior adviser during Ms. Harris’s ascent to state and national politics, and they worked together at the state’s Justice Department.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danny Hakim, Stephanie Saul and Glenn Thrush
title: Stacey Abrams draws credit and praise as Biden inches ahead in Georgia.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: A Cliffhanger of an Election, With One Candidate Leading by Millions
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, November 7, 2020.
content: “Why, when somebody has won millions more votes than their opponent, are we still deliberating over 10,000 votes here, 5,000 votes there?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Senate Majority in Balance as Perdue Re-election Race Goes to Runoff in Georgia
description: Mr. Perdue, a first-term Republican, narrowly failed to clear 50 percent of the vote, sending the race to a January runoff that, along with another runoff contest, will probably determine which party controls the Senate.
content: Control of the Senate hung in the balance on Friday in Georgia after Senator David Perdue, a Republican, fell just short of the majority of votes he needed to win re-election, setting the stage for a second January runoff in the rapidly changing state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Medina, Simon Romero and Matt Stevens
title: In Arizona, Biden maintains his lead as more votes are counted.
description: PHOENIX — Joseph R. Biden Jr. held onto a narrow lead in Arizona after elections officials added thousands more votes to the results there on Saturday morning in what is likely to be one of the last large reports of new vote data from the state.
content: PHOENIX — Joseph R. Biden Jr. held onto a narrow lead in Arizona after elections officials added thousands more votes to the results there on Saturday morning in what is likely to be one of the last large reports of new vote data from the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Flatten Like a Bug
description: Kameron Austin Collins and Paolo Pasco test our resiliency.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Phew, this one is nasty: If you sped through it, take a bow. I expected as much when I saw its byline, Kameron Austin Collins and Paolo Pasco. These two avant-garde constructors are collaborating for us for the first time, and their blizzard of unexpected connections made for treacherous footing, no matter how slowly I crept. Maybe extra feet would have helped.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Biden Victory Brings Sighs of Relief Overseas
description: Foreign leaders showered the president-elect with congratulations. For many, the importance of this election was as much about removing Mr. Trump as ushering in Mr. Biden.
content: LONDON — For a world that held its breath as Americans went to the polls last Tuesday, the triumph of Joseph R. Biden Jr. over President Trump provoked many emotions, but above all, a profound sigh of relief.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan
title: A Somali refugee waiting for his wife and children now awaits election results.
description: Afkab Hussein has barely eaten since Election Day.
content: Afkab Hussein has barely eaten since Election Day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck and Thomas Kaplan
title: Biden, Now President-Elect, Calls for End to ‘Grim Era of Demonization’
description: Joe Biden, in his first post-victory speech, joined his running mate, Senator Kamala Harris, in addressing the country and reached out to President Trump’s supporters. “Let’s give each other a chance,” he said.
content: WILMINGTON, Del. — Joseph R. Biden Jr. addressed the nation for the first time as president-elect on Saturday night, delivering a message of unity and trying to soothe the extraordinary divisions that defined the last four years in American politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise and John Eligon
title: Voters Say Black Lives Matter Protests Were Important. They Disagree On Why.
description: About a fifth of all voters said the protests were the single most important factor in their decision at the ballot box, according to a new survey.
content: The protests that broke out after the police killing of George Floyd in May were some of the biggest racial justice marches organized in decades. In the early weeks, polling showed broad and deep support for them across the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher, Glenn Thrush and Michael D. Shear
title: Biden’s Team Steps Up Transition Plans, Mapping Out a White House
description: With Joe Biden leading in several important battleground states, his advisers and allies have moved rapidly to discuss hiring in critical roles, especially those overseeing the coronavirus response.
content: Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s advisers accelerated their transition planning on Friday as election results showed him with an advantage in battleground states that could hand him the presidency, with the first senior officials in a potential Biden White House possibly named as early as next week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David W. Blight
title: Confronting the Damage of Trumpism
description: The road to his presidency was decades long. The road back won’t be easy.
content: “I speak the password primeval . . . . I give the sign of democracy,” wrote Walt Whitman in “Song of Myself.” “By God! I will accept nothing which all cannot have their counterpart of on the same terms.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: We Are Finally Getting Rid of Him
description: Don’t undersell the triumph of ousting Trump.
content: Before Democrats begin their reckoning over their apparent failure to take the Senate and their reduced numbers in the House, before the intraparty recriminations between centrists and progressives, let’s take a moment to appreciate what’s before us. After four grueling years, Donald Trump has been defeated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Krysten Chambrot
title: 16 Thanksgiving Sides to Make You Forget About the Turkey
description: We all know they’re the best part of the meal.
content: Let’s be honest: Turkey’s great, but Thanksgiving is about the sides. Some of us wait all year for stuffing, potatoes (sweet and regular), green beans and sprouts, mac and cheese — and even the cranberry sauce. To say nothing of rolls!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Mervosh
title: Hope and exhaustion mingle at a college in Ohio.
description: OBERLIN, Ohio — On the roads that lead to Oberlin College, Trump flags tied to telephone poles whip in the wind all year long. But the scene is far different on campus, with a jazz band crooning on Friday evenings and Priuses with bumper stickers that say “be kind.”
content: OBERLIN, Ohio — On the roads that lead to Oberlin College, Trump flags tied to telephone poles whip in the wind all year long. But the scene is far different on campus, with a jazz band crooning on Friday evenings and Priuses with bumper stickers that say “be kind.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karla Cornejo Villavicencio
title: Stephen Miller Will Have Some Free Time Soon
description: What will it mean if Trump is no longer president, and I’m no longer undocumented?
content: NEW HAVEN, Conn. — First, you must know about the birds. The birds are important. My partner and I, we feed birds in our neighborhood. I have a special fondness for the birds that the garden stores that sell marble bird baths consider pests — crows, blackbirds, ravens, blue jays, grackles, starlings. For a while, the crows behind my house brought me gifts, but I felt weird about it. I wasn’t interested in the transaction. I wanted them to trust me. I wanted to be loved.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher, Glenn Thrush and Michael D. Shear
title: Biden’s team is stepping up transition plans, sketching out an administration.
description: Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s advisers accelerated their transition planning on Friday as election results showed him with an advantage in battleground states that could hand him the presidency, with the first senior officials in a potential Biden White House possibly named as early as next week.
content: Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s advisers accelerated their transition planning on Friday as election results showed him with an advantage in battleground states that could hand him the presidency, with the first senior officials in a potential Biden White House possibly named as early as next week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: Republicans and Democrats Agree: End the War on Drugs
description: Voters in red and blue states may be in accord on nothing else, but they passed measures to liberalize drug laws.
content: One of America’s greatest mistakes over the last century was the war on drugs, so it’s thrilling to see voters in red and blue states alike moving to unwind it.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Joe Biden Wins the Presidency: Special Episode of ‘The Daily’
description: The former vice president has been elected the 46th president of the United States. What does his victory mean and what happens now?
content: After days of uncertainty, Joe Biden has been elected president, becoming the first candidate in more than a quarter of a century to beat an incumbent. His running mate, Kamala Harris, is the first woman and woman of color elected vice president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Greg Bensinger
title: Other States Should Worry About What Happened in California
description: The gig companies wrote new labor laws that are almost impossible to change.
content: Uber, Lyft and other gig economy companies congratulated themselves this week for winning a costly fight to overturn legislation in California that would have caused them to treat their contract workers as employees with guaranteed wages and benefits like an unemployment lifeline.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Wait, What?
description: Huh! Evan Kalish and Caitlin Reid bring us a fun Sunday puzzle.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — The title of this puzzle is awfully of the moment, isn’t it? Today we have a collaboration between two very witty constructors, Caitlin Reid and Evan Kalish, their first puzzle as a team and Mr. Kalish’s Sunday Times debut. Interesting tidbit of the week, from their print edition introduction: Postlandia, Mr. Kalish’s loving discourse and visual record of post offices in all 50 states, Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sandra E. Garcia
title: The Uneasy Afterlife of Our Dazzling Trash
description: Where do CDs go to die?
content: Every day, for the past 14 years, Bruce Bennett has received packages filled with CDs. Sometimes a few at a time and sometimes in packs of hundreds, shiny old discs arrive at his CD Recycling Center of America in Salem, N.H., a 300-foot blue trailer tucked behind a commercial strip, to ascend to the CD afterlife.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Is There a Trumpism After Trump?
description: His presidency showed a path to a conservatism that’s multiethnic, middle class and populist. But soon he may stand in its way.
content: Way back in the days after the 2012 election, the last Republican presidential defeat, all the conventional wisdom in American politics converged on a simple idea: The G.O.P. was doomed as a national institution unless it became, in effect, a moderate party of the business class, stiff-arming social conservatives and wooing Hispanic voters by promising more liberal immigration laws.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang and Adam Liptak
title: Pennsylvania’s vote count crawls forward, as Trump scores a minor legal victory.
description: As of early Saturday morning, Joseph R. Biden Jr.  led President Trump in Pennsylvania by 28,833 votes, with 96 percent of the state’s ballots counted. The remaining mail ballots are expected to favor Democrats, and officials in Philadelphia have said it could take a few more days to complete the count there.
content: As of early Saturday morning, Joseph R. Biden Jr.  led President Trump in Pennsylvania by 28,833 votes, with 96 percent of the state’s ballots counted. The remaining mail ballots are expected to favor Democrats, and officials in Philadelphia have said it could take a few more days to complete the count there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Rutenberg, Alan Feuer, Nick Corasaniti and Reid J. Epstein
title: Here’s a review of the array of Republican legal challenges to the ballot counting.
description: Nearly a dozen lawsuits filed by President Trump and his allies are working their way through the courts in Nevada, Pennsylvania, Michigan and Georgia, trying — so far unsuccessfully — to stop ballot counting and invalidate enough votes to erase Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s leads there. Here is a look at those cases.
content: Nearly a dozen lawsuits filed by President Trump and his allies are working their way through the courts in Nevada, Pennsylvania, Michigan and Georgia, trying — so far unsuccessfully — to stop ballot counting and invalidate enough votes to erase Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s leads there. Here is a look at those cases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: Biden’s Big Challenge
description: The unity message won. Now it will face a test.
content: The New York Times has called the race in Pennsylvania for Joe Biden, and with it, the presidency of the United States. He has defeated Donald Trump, who becomes the country’s first one-term commander in chief in nearly three decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller
title: In Oakland, the birthplace of Kamala Harris, the mayor says, ‘It is like a whole new world.’
description: In Oakland, Calif., the birthplace of Vice President-elect Kamala Harris, Mayor Libby Schaaf was in tears on Saturday as she spoke about the victory.
content: In Oakland, Calif., the birthplace of Vice President-elect Kamala Harris, Mayor Libby Schaaf was in tears on Saturday as she spoke about the victory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman
title: Along the Seine, Booksellers Try to Hold Off an Unhappy Ending
description: The coronavirus lockdowns have taken a steep toll on Paris’s “bouquinistes,” whose bookstalls stretch for miles along the Seine. “We are barely making enough to eat.”
content: PARIS — On a recent breezy day, Jérôme Callais wrapped a secondhand biography of Robespierre tightly in cellophane, covering the burgundy leather hardcover with an expert flick of the wrist and positioning it near a weighty tome on Talleyrand inside his dark green bookstand on a quai above the Seine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon
title: Minneapolis residents say new leaders can’t always solve old problems.
description: MINNEAPOLIS — At the site where George Floyd was killed by the Minneapolis police in May, Romell Jernagin said on Friday that persistent issues plaguing his community, such as police brutality and gang activity, were unlikely to be solved by new political leadership.
content: MINNEAPOLIS — At the site where George Floyd was killed by the Minneapolis police in May, Romell Jernagin said on Friday that persistent issues plaguing his community, such as police brutality and gang activity, were unlikely to be solved by new political leadership.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nic Wirtz and Kirk Semple
title: Guatemala Rescuers Search for Scores of People Buried in Mudslide Caused by Eta
description: More than 100 are feared dead in what is likely to be the deadliest episode of a storm that has already claimed more than 60 lives in Central America.
content: ANTIGUA, Guatemala — Rescue teams on Saturday dug through mud and debris in a remote village in central Guatemala searching for more than 100 people whose homes were swallowed by a massive mudslide caused by rainfall from remnants of Hurricane Eta.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer and Sydney Ember
title: Kamala Harris Makes History as First Woman and Woman of Color as Vice President
description: Ms. Harris, the daughter of an Indian mother and Jamaican father, has risen higher in the country’s leadership than any woman ever before her.
content: From the earliest days of her childhood, Kamala Harris was taught that the road to racial justice was long.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: The Key States Biden Won en Route to the White House
description: Joe Biden had to flip a few states that went to President Trump in 2016 and hold on to Democratic-leaning battleground states to win the election. Here’s how it happened.
content: After days of vote counting, former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. has amassed the 270 Electoral College votes he needed to secure the presidency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed O'Loughlin
title: Irish Home of Biden’s Great-Great-Great Grandfather Cheers His Victory
description: He may be five generations removed, but the president-elect is a hometown boy in Ballina, Ireland.
content: BALLINA, Ireland — As America turned slowly blue, Ballina held its breath.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: What’s Still Left to Count, and Why Hasn’t a Winner Been Called?
description: Biden’s lead is expected to expand again in Pennsylvania today.
content: Joe Biden keeps inching closer to victory. He now leads in states worth over 300 electoral votes. Outside of Arizona, virtually all of the remaining vote appears likely to increase his margins. So why hasn’t the race for president been called?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yuval Noah Harari
title: At Home With Our Ancient Cousins, the Neanderthals
description: In “Kindred,” Rebecca Wragg Sykes offers a complete new story about Neanderthals, both how they lived and how they met their end.
content: KINDREDNeanderthal Life, Love, Death and ArtBy Rebecca Wragg Sykes
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Top Republicans Are Silent on Biden Victory as Trump Refuses to Concede
description: The top Senate Republican issued no statement congratulating President-elect Biden, while a leading House Republican echoed President Trump’s protestations that the election was not, in fact, over.
content: WASHINGTON — As President Trump refused to concede defeat on Saturday, top Republican congressional leaders followed suit, refraining from releasing the customary statements congratulating the victor that have been standard among senior lawmakers in both parties when a presidential election has been declared.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Dobbins and Manny Fernandez
title: In Texas, an Emerging Problem for Democrats on the Border
description: In their long-running bid for Texas, Democrats ran into trouble. Trump antagonized immigrants, but he also won new voters who live along the border.
content: ZAPATA, Texas — Democrats spent years focusing on how they could finally win Texas. But since Tuesday’s election, they have been wrestling with a more pressing question: How did they lose Zapata County?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caroline Randall Williams
title: A Loving Chastisement for America
description: “Love does not mean what the white man has traditionally thought it meant,” my grandfather wrote.
content: NASHVILLE — On Nov. 8, 2016, I was teaching at Fisk, a historically Black university. At the end of class, I told my students to brace for the next day. I’d just spent the last six years living in Mississippi and then in West Virginia, and I was 100 percent certain that Hillary Clinton was going to lose.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Barry
title: For a Trump Fan, a Week When Victory Ebbed Away
description: Nick Rocco, a passionate Trump follower in the Democratic bastion of Massachusetts, slowly realized it wasn’t going his way.
content: WILMINGTON, Mass. — Nick Rocco went into Election Day amped up. A 26-year-old hair stylist, he spent the past few months campaigning for President Trump, taking special satisfaction in offending Biden supporters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allan Kreda
title: Pandemic Creates New Considerations for Arena Construction
description: The Islanders’ new home at Belmont Park and the venue for the expansion Seattle Kraken have added safety measures for their plans to host fans when they open in 2021.
content: Tim Leiweke could hardly contain his enthusiasm while he gestured toward what will be center ice at the Islanders’ future home at Belmont Park.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: In photos: Night falls on a nation still without election results.
description: For some, that meant continuing to tally votes. But others were able to let loose — or looser, at least — toward the end of an exhausting week.
content: For some, that meant continuing to tally votes. But others were able to let loose — or looser, at least — toward the end of an exhausting week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin and Alexander Burns
title: Biden Wins Presidency, Ending Four Tumultuous Years Under Trump
description: Joseph R. Biden Jr. achieved victory offering a message of healing and unity. He will return to Washington facing a daunting set of crises.
content: Joseph Robinette Biden Jr. was elected the 46th president of the United States on Saturday, promising to restore political normalcy and a spirit of national unity to confront raging health and economic crises, and making Donald J. Trump a one-term president after four years of tumult in the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Davey Alba
title: No, 20,000 Dead People in Pennsylvania Did Not Vote
description: The viral claim stemmed from a lawsuit that a federal judge in the state had already cast doubt on.
content: President Trump and others have repeatedly brought up the falsehood that 20,000 dead people on voter rolls in Pennsylvania fraudulently had their votes recorded in this month’s election. In some versions of the rumor, those deceased people had voted for the Democratic presidential candidate, Joseph R. Biden Jr.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Our 21 Favorite Thanksgiving Recipes
description: Try recommendations from members of The New York Times Food department.
content: If the idea of putting together a holiday menu is too much right now, here are 21 beloved dishes recommended by members of The New York Times Food department. You could make Millie Peartree’s Southern macaroni and cheese (above), Julia Reed’s bourbon pecan pie or any of the recipes in the collection below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: Do Emotional-Support Pets Pose a Covid Risk in Apartment Buildings?
description: Laws prohibiting discrimination against people with disabilities, not to mention coronavirus science, make it hard for apartment buildings to ban emotional-support animals.
content: Q: I live in a Manhattan condo with a no-pet policy. I recently requested an exception to the rule because I need a dog as an emotional-support animal. The board rejected my request, claiming that because there is no definitive proof that dogs cannot spread coronavirus to humans, permitting one in the building endangers the health of residents. This seems absurd to me. Can the board really reject my request on these grounds? What can I do to appeal the decision?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Van Jones, breaking down on CNN, invokes George Floyd’s words in declaring Trump’s loss a ‘vindication.’
description: The election of Joseph R. Biden Jr. elicited powerful reactions across the nation but few are resonating as deeply as the emotional on-air response to President Trump’s defeat by the CNN contributor Van Jones — who invoked George Floyd’s dying words in expressing his sense of relief and vindication.
content: The election of Joseph R. Biden Jr. elicited powerful reactions across the nation but few are resonating as deeply as the emotional on-air response to President Trump’s defeat by the CNN contributor Van Jones — who invoked George Floyd’s dying words in expressing his sense of relief and vindication.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Mike Ives
title: Six White House aides, including Trump’s chief of staff, have the coronavirus.
description: Mark Meadows, the White House chief of staff, has contracted the coronavirus, as have five other White House aides and a Trump campaign adviser, officials say, raising fears of another outbreak sweeping through the ranks of the nation’s top officials.
content: Mark Meadows, the White House chief of staff, has contracted the coronavirus, as have five other White House aides and a Trump campaign adviser, officials say, raising fears of another outbreak sweeping through the ranks of the nation’s top officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman, Sabrina Tavernise and Lucy Tompkins
title: ‘A New Day in America’: Biden Victory Prompts Spontaneous Celebrations
description: Scenes of jubilation spread minutes after news outlets had called the election for Joseph R. Biden Jr. They lasted into the night.
content: CHICAGO — People shouting from their windows, ringing cowbells on their porches and blaring car horns in the streets: As the news spread through cellphones and television screens that Joseph R. Biden Jr. had won the presidential election, spontaneous celebrations erupted within minutes across the nation, and many persisted as street parties into the night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset and Stephanie Saul
title: With a small margin in Georgia, a recount is inevitable, state officials say.
description: Joe Biden leads President Trump by about 7,000 votes as of Saturday morning.
content: ATLANTA — The presidential race in Georgia is so close that a recount is inevitable, Georgia’s secretary of state said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck and Thomas Kaplan
title: A President-Elect Shaped by Tragedy and Tradition
description: Joseph R. Biden Jr. has spent his career devoted to institutions and relationships. And those are the tools he will rely on to govern a fractured nation.
content: Thirty-three years ago, he was the fast-talking junior senator from Delaware with a chip on his shoulder, desperate to prove his gravitas during a brief, ill-fated presidential run.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: Joe Biden is elected the 46th president of the United States.
description: WILMINGTON, Del. — Joseph R. Biden Jr. was elected president of the United States on Saturday, defeating President Trump after campaigning on a promise to restore civility and stability to American politics and to expand the government’s role in guiding the country through the surging coronavirus pandemic.
content: WILMINGTON, Del. — Joseph R. Biden Jr. was elected president of the United States on Saturday, defeating President Trump after campaigning on a promise to restore civility and stability to American politics and to expand the government’s role in guiding the country through the surging coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Michael D. Shear
title: Denial, and Resignation, From Trump and a Handful of Aides
description: Aides said the president had no plans to immediately deliver the kind of concession speech that has become traditional in past elections, and his campaign vowed to continue waging its legal battle across the country.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s motorcade was just pulling into the Trump National Golf Club in suburban Virginia on Saturday morning when news organizations ended days of waiting and declared that he had lost the presidency to Joseph R. Biden Jr.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: Wedding Vendors Find Profits in the Backyard
description: As lockdown orders lightened, couples have opted for small outdoor ceremonies, and with them, came the need for caterers, photographers and other vendors.
content: During the March coronavirus lockdown, Melissa Fahlstrom, the owner of Sugar Whipped Bakery, a Plattsburg, Mo., business that specializes in wedding cakes, had feared the worst. “I panicked that my business would come to a crashing halt,” she said. “I could last two months to pay my mortgage, my loan, my overhead costs.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Branch
title: At Cal, a Single Positive Test May Wipe Out Two Football Games
description: On Saturday, the Pac-12 will become the last major college conference to start its football season. But Cal’s Golden Bears, despite following strict protocols, won’t be on the field, and they might have to miss next week’s game, too.
content: For months, the athletic department at Cal thought it was doing everything just right to keep the coronavirus out and get games going again. The football team’s season opener on Saturday was supposed to be the university’s first athletic competition since March. Like hundreds of other colleges, Cal was determined to make it happen, safely.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Collins, Ford Fessenden, Lazaro Gamio, Rich Harris, John Keefe, Denise Lu, Eleanor Lutz, Amy Schoenfeld Walker, Derek Watkins and Karen Yourish
title: How Biden Flipped Pennsylvania and Won the Election
description: As eastern counties shifted left, Joe Biden was propelled into victory in a state that President Trump narrowly won in 2016.
content: As eastern counties shifted left, Joe Biden was propelled into victory in a state that President Trump narrowly won in 2016.
source.name: The New York Times

author: Photographs by Philip Montgomery
title: Democracy Worked This Year. But It Is Under Threat.
description: America’s pandemic election was a remarkable, unlikely feat — conducted under assault from its president.
content: America’s pandemic election was a remarkable, unlikely feat — conducted under assault from its president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Rhyne
title: Protesters Dance Outside Philadelphia Vote-Counting Site
description: Large groups of demonstrators gathered outside the Pennsylvania Convention Center Friday night as the Democratic presidential nominee Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s lead increased in the battleground state.
content: Large groups of demonstrators gathered outside the Pennsylvania Convention Center Friday night as the Democratic presidential nominee Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s lead increased in the battleground state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chai Dingari
title: You Can Do This, Donald Trump
description: It’s hard to concede. But voters have spoken.
content: It’s hard to concede. But voters have spoken.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Cheers Ring Out in Cities Across the Nation After Biden’s Win
description: Mass celebrations and smaller protests broke out around the country after Joseph R. Biden Jr. defeated President Trump in the election for the presidency of the United States.
content: Mass celebrations and smaller protests broke out around the country after Joseph R. Biden Jr. defeated President Trump in the election for the presidency of the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ainara Tiefenthäler, Nilo Tabrizy, Natalie Reneau and Drew Jordan
title: Kamala Harris’s History of Firsts
description: A senator from California and a former prosecutor, Ms. Harris has a track record in breaking new ground. Now, she is the first woman, first Black person, and first person of Asian descent elected to the country’s second-highest office.
content: A senator from California and a former prosecutor, Ms. Harris has a track record in breaking new ground. Now, she is the first woman, first Black person, and first person of Asian descent elected to the country’s second-highest office.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Looking Back at the Trump Years
description: Readers react to the reflections of New York Times columnists in a special Sunday Review issue.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Nov. 7, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Nov. 7, 2020.
content: An article on Oct. 31 about tax loopholes in the real estate industry that have benefited President Trump misstated the effect of 2017 changes to a tax break for rehabilitating historic structures. The law limited the tax break to 4 percent a year, but allowed it to be credited in five consecutive years for a total of 20 percent of the project’s cost. It did not lower the tax credit to 4 percent from 20 percent. The article also misstated the timing of an exemption for the tax break. The exemption applied to projects started before mid-2018, not before 2017.
source.name: The New York Times

title: With President-Elect Joe Biden, ‘the Long National Nightmare Is Over’
description: “I am writing this with tears of joy streaming down my face,” a reader told us. And he is not alone: a sampling of the reaction.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
